definition: To hold or have inside; to include.
examples: This bottle contains one litre of water.
Many stories contain a lesson.

definition: To break down food or understand information; a short collection or summary of information.
examples: Your body digests food after you eat. (verb)
We read a weekly news digest. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Di-gest = ‘get’ information or food inside properly.

definition: Hard to please; fussy about small details.
examples: The cat is finicky about its food.
He’s finicky when choosing colours.

definition: Something you do often, usually without thinking.
examples: Brushing your teeth at night is a good habit.
He has a habit of tapping his pencil.

extra.memory_tip: Habit = what you ‘have it’ in your routine.

definition: A joint that lets a door or lid open and close; to depend on something.
examples: The gate swings on a metal hinge. (noun)
Our plan hinges on the weather. (verb)

definition: Soft, wet land with grasses and shallow water.
examples: We saw ducks nesting in the marsh.
Marsh plants grow in soggy soil.

definition: A room or place for caring for babies or young children; a place where young plants are grown.
examples: The nursery has story time every morning.
We bought tomato seedlings from the plant nursery.

definition: To depend on someone or something with confidence.
examples: You can rely on Sam to be on time.
Plants rely on sunlight to grow.

extra.memory_tip: ReLY = lean on; you ‘lie’ your weight on it.

definition: The backbone in your body; the narrow back edge of a book; a sharp, pointed part on a plant or animal.
examples: The spine protects the spinal cord.
The book’s title is printed on the spine.

extra.memory_tip: Spine = the line that supports your shape.

definition: To grow well and be healthy; to do very well.
examples: Cacti thrive in dry, sunny places.
With practice, her confidence thrived.
